text: We previously utilized a gnotobiotic piglet infection model to determine that piglets infected with <extra_id_0> deltanleH1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutant died more rapidly than those infected with wild-type E . coli O157 : H7 .

Piglets infected with <extra_id_0> deltanleH1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> displayed clinical disease consistent with a robust inflammatory response , but with reduced bacterial colonization and little diarrhea9 .

While seemingly paradoxical , based on our cell culture data ( Fig . 6d ) , we hypothesized that <extra_id_0> NleH1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> blocked <extra_id_0> RPS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> S209 phosphorylation in vivo , thereby preventing <extra_id_0> RPS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> nuclear translocation in infected piglets .

text: We isolated piglet colons at necropsy , and subjected them to immunohistochemistry using our phospho - RPS3 antibody .

Consistent with in vitro data , piglets infected with wild-type E . coli O157 : H7 exhibited diffuse and low intensity phospho - <extra_id_0> RPS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> staining , whereas in piglets infected with <extra_id_0> deltanleH1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutant , phospho - <extra_id_0> RPS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was florid and intense ( Fig . 6f ) .
